items.text: When I was young, I thought house painters painted houses. We glimpse some of the elderly men and women in the rooms, but like everyone else in their lives, disregard them and keep looking for someone else.
What did I know? We turn a corner into another hallway, keep looking -
I was a working guy. We drift into a rec room where more elderly men and women watch TV, play cards, stare off at nothing -

A business agent for Teamster Local One-O-Seven out of South Philadelphia... We approach a particular man sitting apart from the others in a wheelchair.  He’s about 80, better dressed than everyone else here, white dress shirt, cuffs monogrammed FJS, dark slacks, aviator sunglasses.

One of a thousand working stiffs... This is who we’ve been looking for - Frank Sheeran - perhaps to kill him.  But he pays no attention to us, even as we come in close enough to see his gold watch encircled with diamonds, and the distinctive ring made from a gold coin on a finger.

... until I wasn’t anymore... TWO QUICK GUNSHOTS to the back of an UNKNOWN MAN’S head. The blank wall explodes in red, as though a bucket of blood had been thrown against it. The blood begins to slowly ooze down the wall covering it with red streaks.
... And started painting houses myself.
In this particular matter, the whole thing was built around the wedding.

Bill Bufalino’s daughter was getting married in Detroit. Frank puts the watch on his wrist.  The gold ring is on his finger next to his wedding band.  He’s quite a bit younger than when we saw him at the assisted living facility.  About 55.
Bill was a Teamster lawyer, but more important, he was Russell Bufalino’s cousin. He zips a suit and shirt into a garment bag like a body in a body bag.
Russell didn’t want to fly.  He wanted to take care of some business along the way.
Business in Russell’s case means one thing: collecting money.  So we’d drive.  Him and his wife Carrie and me and Irene.
We’d take 476 out of Philly up to Pittston - then I-80 West through the rest of Pennsylvania - across Ohio to Toledo - then 75 North to Detroit.

It was gonna take three days with all the business breaks and cigarette stops since Russell didn’t allow smoking in the car. He says Jimmy Blue Eyes and Meyer Lansky convinced him to stop when they were getting kicked out of their casinos in Cuba and getting shot at by Castro. I don’t know. It might have been one of those: “Please-God-if-I-ever-get-out-of-this-alive-I’ll-never-smoke-again-things”, but I do know that from Castro on Russ wouldn’t let anybody smoke in the car, even Carrie.
Can we stop soon?
We’re not even to the highway.
You won’t stop on the highway.
It’s not safe to stop on the highway.
Then we’ll smoke in the car.
The smoke’s bad for my cataracts.
I’ll crack the window.
Carrie - I made a vow.
And I can’t smoke in the car?
Or on the highway. Carrie isn’t having it; snaps open her little gold lamé cigarette clutch.  She cracks the window. Russell glances over at Frank through his thick glasses and sighs.
You see where we are?
What are the odds? They regard the unremarkable surroundings like they weren’t so unremarkable, including a Stuckey’s/Texaco gas station up the road.  A tractor-trailer roars past and -
What’s the matter, kid?
I don’t know.  Sounds funny. Frank runs the engine manually from under the hood as Russell listens.
(finally) It’s your timing chain. He selects a wrench from Frank’s tools and makes an adjustment. In a few moments the engine is sounding normal again.
This fix won’t last forever. Russell wipes his hands on a rag and heads off.
Jeezus! Thanks. What do I owe you? Russell waves back, ‘nothing,’ and Frank watches him walk into the gas station.
I thought maybe he owned the gas station.  He owned something, you could tell.
It turns out he owned the whole road.
Skinny Razor got the name because he started out as a kid killing live chickens at his father’s butcher shop.
That’s Skinny Razor.  He owns the place. He shylocks and runs a little book out of the joint. You should meet him.
Did you say razor?
He used to work at a butcher shop.
Skinny, this is Frank.
You got something for me?
You like steak?
I own the joint don’t I?
I deliver steak.
That’s what I hear.
I could deliver you steak. Johnny gives Skinny a nod that says “yes”.
Have a drink. As the bartender serves drinks, Skinny toasts the group.
It’s harder to steal in the summer when the weather’s nice. He shuts the truck’s rear doors.  The yard manager slaps an aluminum seal on the lock.
Winter’s a different story.
It’s freezing out there.
I don’t mind it.
Not me. I hate it. Will you do me a favor and put on the seal?
Sure. I’ve gotta be out there anyway. The Yard Manager hands Frank the aluminum seal, and turns away to warm his hands over a small floor heater.
I owe you one.
(to some dock guys) I’ll give you a hand.
Delicious.
It’s all Prime meat. I don’t go near “Choice”.
Then keep’em coming, Frank.

First I was stealing five hindquarters at a time.  Then ten. Twelve.  Things were missing everywhere I went.  I was doing real good, but then - The doors open revealing no hindquarters inside.  Frank looks mystified.
What the fuck?
What the fuck is this?
I don’t know, it’s not my job to load.  Maybe the loaders didn’t do their job. Everyone on the dock looks at Frank.
You didn’t notice you were driving a light horse?
No, I thought I had a good horse.
Under the contract, thanks to Jimmy Hoffa, management can only fire a driver on specific charges.
Ever show up late?
No. 10
Any moving violations?
No.
You drink on the job?
No.
Ever hit anybody?
On the job?
Yeah.
No. The lawyer nods to himself - all this seems to be satisfactory to him - and he seems to have exhausted the list of fireable offenses.
Stealing isn’t grounds?
Can they prove it?
I don’t think so.
Then no. They regard each other.
If they could prove it, all they’re going to want from you is names.  Accomplices. You could keep your job and walk away. Would you give them names to keep your job?
No. Bill nods.  That’s the right answer.  Then -
You know I don’t care if you did it or not.
Yeah.
It makes no difference to me.  I’m here to defend you.  Right?
Yeah.
(whispers) But did you? Frank isn’t sure if he’s supposed to admit it or not to his lawyer.  Eventually -
I work hard for that company when I’m not stealing from them. Bill smiles.  He likes Frank.  He won’t be the last to appreciate his honest dishonesty.

Your Honor, if this were about right and wrong, the company would have sought Mr. Sheeran’s dismissal.  They didn’t.  They only brought charges against Mr. Sheeran because the company hoped that he would name the conspirators he couldn’t give them because they don’t exist.  They don’t exist because he never stole anything.  He never stole anything because he’s an exemplary employee who in eight years has never taken a day of sick leave.

The only rule he ever broke was his own union’s, by helping others carry sides of beef from his truck to their refrigerators in the dead of winter. With that and all else he’s heard, the judge renders judgement -
I’m dismissing this case with a warning -
Yes, your Honor.

Not you, Mr. Sheeran. The plaintiff. You bring another workingman before this court with threats instead of evidence, believe me, you’ll be sorry. (shakes his head) If I owned stock in this company, I’d sell it.
I don’t know how he did it, and I’m not gonna ask. Angelo Bruno watches Frank walk from the entrance to the hat checking area with Bill Bufalino.
All I know is that Bill Bufalino got me out of a case where I should’a gone down for the count. Angelo Bruno continues to watch as a WAITRESS helps Frank and Bill with their coats.
Instead, we went out celebrating and I met what was gonna turn out to be the rest of my life.
Bill Bufalino is surprised to see his cousin, RUSSELL BUFALINO, at the restaurant and headed for a table.  Bill Bufalino acknowledges his cousin with a kiss.
Frank, this is my cousin, Russell Bufalino. Frank recognizes Russell Bufalino as the man who helped him with his truck.
(to Russell) Hey, didn’t you help me out with my truck a couple of months ago?
Yeah. It was nothing. It was that timing chain. They’re tricky. Did you get it fixed?
Yeah. The next day. Thanks again.

(teasing) Watch yourself with these tough guys around here. Alright, maybe I see you around. (You did the right thing.) A smiling Russell shakes hands with Frank and walks alone toward his own table as Bill and Frank are led to theirs.
(to Bill) Your cousin saved my ass. I could have lost the whole load.
Yeah. He knows everything about trucks. He worked for Canada Dry. Frank looks over to where Russell is being seated.

I might not have known who Russell Bufalino was back then, but I had seen enough pictures and stories in the newspapers to know he was eating with Angelo Bruno, the new boss of Philadelphia, who ran everything from Philadelphia to Atlantic City. That was all I had to know that Russell Bufalino was no truck mechanic from Canada Dry.
(Italian, subtitled) It’s very good bread.  Thank you.
(Italian, subtitled) Where’d a Paddy learn to speak Italian?
(Italian, subtitled) In Sicily.  The war. Russell is pleased and impressed with Frank’s Italian, but even more so that he was in the war. They continue in Italian (wherever italicized)-
Where?
Catania.
I’m from Catania. How long?
Four years. 411 combat days. (in Italian) 122 at Anzio. (back to English) 45th Infantry.
It was bad there. Frank nods, but doesn’t elaborate.
Did you think you’d die?

You think about it... you’re scared... but once the action starts, the fear goes away because you’re too busy fighting... I made it through the war so now, I look around... I think... what happens, happens.
Fuck it. Russell nods, leaves it at that.
You got orders, you’d follow them. They tell you take some prisoners out to the woods - they don’t say “what to do” - they’d just say... like... “Hurry back”.
That’s war.

You know it’s crazy but I never understood how they would just keep digging. Their own graves, y’know? Maybe they thought if they did a good job... the guy with the gun... German Soldiers #1 and #2 have finished digging and look up plaintively at Frank for mercy.
... would change his mind. Frank shoots the Germans. They fall into the hole.

items.speaker_cue_raw: BACK TO THE VILLA DI ROMA
items.text: To Frank and Russell -
People cling to hope.
Russell took a shine to me. It wasn’t long before he had me doing little things for him and Angelo Bruno, himself.
Carrie’s family went back to the same town in Sicily as the Bufalinos. They talked about it all the time. She came from the Sciandras. To them it was like they came over on the Italian Mayflower.
What happened? Russell gives her a look.
Go get washed and give me the shirt, I’ll put it in the wash. He takes off the bloody shirt and hands it to her.
Don’t forget your shoes. As Carrie goes off to wash his shirt, Russell bends down to remove his bloodied shoes. He sets a gun down.
Can we stop, Frank?
Where are we?
Outside Lewisburg.
I got some things to do in Lewisburg. Wake me up when we get there. Russell closes his eyes to nap.

He had a piece of everything, but mostly he ran his business out of Penn Drape and Curtains. Who knew what it all was?  I’m sure the man had partners. They always have partners. Nobody keeps all the money, but everybody listened to Russ. And when you did something for Russ, you did it yourself. Like he said -
I don’t need two roads coming back to me.
When Anastasia got killed in the barber shop, it was Russell who calmed things down so they weren’t killing each other before it could all get straightened out.
Still, you’d never know it by looking at him. But all the roads led back to Russ.
I was helping out Skinny and his friends with collections. Skinny comes down the steps of his house in a robe and slippers.
That’s all Skinny did. Grill steaks and collect money. Skinny pokes his head in the passenger window.  Doesn’t see what he expects to see.
Where’s the money?
He didn’t have it.  He (said) -
Don’t tell me, let me guess. His mother died and the funeral set him back.
Yeah.
His fuckin mother’s been dying over and over for ten years. Don’t leave. Skinny scampers back into the house and reemerges a moment later with a paper bag in his hand.
Don’t use it.  Just show it to him. Skinny sets the bag on the passenger seat and trots back to his house.  Frank sees a gun in the bag and drives off.
In those days, you took along a gun just to show a guy.  Today, they shoot you with it. The guy is terrified by the mere sight of the gun in the open bag. They both get into the car.
In those days, you wanted your money tomorrow. These days, they want it yesterday.
Tomorrow.
Tomorrow.  I swear.
Here.
Here.  Tomorrow. Skinny nods, Okay, go.  But the guy doesn’t go.
What.
How am I going to get home?
Take a fuckin bus, get out of here. The deadbeat leaves.
What’s the matter with her?
Nothing. She knocked over something in the grocery store and made a mess. The grocer yelled at her and shoved her out.
He pushed her? Frank turns to Peggy.
He pushed you? Peggy nods.
The grocery on the corner? Peggy nods.
(to Peggy, sweetly) Come with me sweetheart. Show me.
Frank, it was an accident.
That him? Peggy nods.
You go home, sweetheart. Tell your mother I’ll be right there. Okay? Okay? He kisses her on the top of her head and sends her home. He then turns toward the grocery store.

Frank, I’m sorry, but your kid was out of line. I only did what you and your wife should have done at home. Frank pulls the Grocer clear over the counter and slams him on the floor. Frank then takes aim for a second and stomps on the guy’s hand with all his weight.
It was a beautiful occasion. Everybody showed up.(more to come)
You wanna pick up a quick ten grand? Whispers is true to his name speaking so softly Frank has to lean over to hear.
This is not the Whispers they blew up in that car around the same time... FLASHCUT to a car blowing up.  Then back to the diner - Whispers continuing to fill Frank in on the job.
This is the other Whispers. The good one who knew how to make money.
It’s a great business.
We supply all the bed sheets, towels, and linen to most of the Atlantic City casinos and hotels. We pick it up, wash it, iron it, and deliver it. Until recently, it’s been a license to print money.

Except there’s this fuckin’ laundry down in Delaware that’s knocking us dead. They’re cutting the price. They’re scaring our drivers. They’re sucking up more and more of our business.  I’m a little concerned.
Whenever anybody says they’re a little concerned, they are very concerned.  When they say they’re more than a little concerned, they’re desperate.
I’m more than a little concerned.
We’ve gotta put these fuckin guys out of business somehow.
Yeah. Frank takes a quick look inside the envelope.
This isn’t ten grand.

I know. Don’t worry. You know I’m good for it. I didn’t wanna go on the street asking for that kind of money and have anybody asking questions. Frank looks at him, not sure he can trust him to pay up.

What’s the matter, Frank? Take it. What am I gonna do stiff you for the money. You think I’m nuts? I’m looking to put these Delaware bastards out of business and we’ll all be good. Frank finally puts the envelope in his pocket.
And remember, please!  This is between us.  Don’t mention nothing to nobody, even Skinny.  That’s why I didn’t wanna borrow the ten grand off the street.
I hit on a ten-dollar daily double. She knows it isn’t true, but doesn’t care.  Peggy knows it isn’t true and does care.
Angelo wants to see you. Frank jumps in Skinny’s car.
Sit down, Frank. Frank sits.  Listens to a silence before -
What’re you doing in Delaware? Frank glances from Angelo Bruno - who’s studying him - to Russell Bufalino - who isn’t - and wisely decides to tell the truth.
Bombing out a laundry service.
For who? (nothing from Frank) This is not one of those times to not say.
For Whispers.  The other Whispers.
You know who owns the Cadillac Linen Service?
Some Jews in the laundry business.
They own part of it.  Somebody else has an interest in that.  You know who?
No.
I do.
Who.
No.  I do.  I own the other part. Not I know who owns the other part.
I didn’t know that.
Whispers didn’t tell you it was the Jew mob?
He said Jew washerwomen.
Jew washerwomen.  What else he say?  I’ll bet he said keep it to yourself.  Don’t say nothin’ to nobody Downtown. Frank nods.  Listens to the amplified sounds.  Then -
I didn’t check.  I’m sorry, I should’ve checked. You want me to give him his money back?
He won’t need it.  You can keep it.
You sure?
He won’t need it.
Thank you.
Thank Russell.  I wouldn’t have wasted my time.  I’d have let the Jews have you.
(to Russell) Thank you.

It’s best to use something brand new. Right out of the box. Otherwise, you don’t know where it’s been. What somebody did with it you don’t even know about. Whispers sees Frank come around the corner and walk toward him - a friend walking toward a friend - as if to give him a tip on a race or football game.
So I recommend something new right out of the box. Frank shoots him with a .32 and keeps walking.
Naturally, the next thing you want to do is throw it away. (ALT: ...get rid of it.)
There’s a spot in the Schuylkill River everybody uses. They ever send divers down there, they’d be able to arm a small country.
With Whispers, it broke the ice.
It was like the army.
You followed orders.
And when I handled things for Russell it was never for money, but as a show of respect. You ran a little errand, you did a favor, you got a little favor back if you ever needed it.
And you always hurried back. IRENE, the waitress, smiles and affectionately touches Frank’s shoulder as she clears the dishes.
No time is a good time to leave your wife, but that’s when I left mine. They disappear into a cheap hotel.

Here it is. Frank pulls to the curb in front of a fur shop.  Gets out, leaving the motor running, goes inside.  Comes back out a moment later with an envelope of cash which he gives to Russell who puts it in the glove compartment, shuts it.
I think that kid’s a-scared of me.
She’s a-scared of me, too.  She’s one of those sensitive kids.  You know.

That’s not good, Frank. She shouldn’t be a-scared of you. You gotta be close with your daughters, you know. You gotta be close with your family. You’re blessed to have them. I told you Carrie and I, you know, we can’t have kids, you know. So you’re blessed. Bufalino motions Peggy to join him and her father.
Sweetheart, do you know why God made the sky so high?
No.
Because he didn’t want the birds to bang their heads. Peggy is expressionless.
(still trying) You want candy or something to eat?
No. Peggy goes back to bowling and starts laughing with Maryanne.
Maybe it’s okay that she’s a-scared of me, but she shouldn’t be a-scared of you. You’re her father. You’ve got to keep an eye on that.
You’re right.
It happens sometimes in a divorce. The kids get nervous. They start resenting you.
I’m lucky the way Mary and Renie get along. The kids move back and forth with no problems.
It can make all the difference, when the parents ain’t at war. Russell looks over and smiles and waves to Peggy, but she looks away.
You good with the union?
You kidding? Best union in the world.
Well, a good friend of ours is gonna need some help.
Yeah? Who?
I mean the top guy. He’s gonna need some help.
You mean Hoffa?
He’s got people who are looking to make trouble. Some bastards tried to pipe him over a workman’s comp case.
I heard he beat the shit out of them.
Yeah, but he’s still gonna need somebody he can trust.
Right on time. Skinny answers the phone.

(into the phone) Skinny. (listening) How you doing? Good. And the family? Yeah, we’re all good. Knock wood. Oh yeah, Angelo’s fine. He got a good physical with the doctor last week. He’s in the pink. Knock wood again. Let me give McGee the phone. You take care of yourself, you hear. Skinny hands the phone to Russell. But Russell doesn’t talk into it he walks the phone over to Frank’s table and sits down. He puts an envelope on the table.
(into the phone) I got that friend I told you about. He’s sitting here with me. He’s a good union man. I want him to meet his president. See what you think of him. Russell hands Frank the phone.
Say hello.
(into the phone) Hello?
Hi Frank. It’s Jimmy Hoffa. The image of Frank and Russell at the table slows down.
Nowadays, young people don’t know who Jimmy Hoffa was.  Maybe they know he disappeared, that’s about it.  But back then, there wasn’t an American alive who didn’t know who he was.
Hiya, Frank. This is Jimmy Hoffa. Glad to meet you, even over the phone.
In the 50’s, he was as famous as Elvis.  In the 60’s, he was as famous as the Beatles.  Next to the President he was the most powerful man in the country.
If you got it, a truck brought it to you.  Food, clothing, medicine, fuel for homes and industry.  The day our trucks stop America stops.

items.speaker_cue_raw: BACK TO THE VILLA DI ROMA
items.text: as the slow-motion image of Frank on the phone and Russell at the table returns to normal -
I heard you paint houses.
I do my own carpentry too.
That’s what I wanted to hear. I understand you’re a brother of mine.
Local 107.  Since 1947.
Our friend speaks very highly of you.
Thank you.
He’s not an easy man to please.
I do my best.
Hoffa speaking to the workers -
We are facing a struggle as never before. The most important thing the labor movement cannot do without is solidarity. Big business has been on the attack -

items.speaker_cue_raw: BACK TO THE VILLA DI ROMA
items.text: Frank still on the phone with Hoffa -
- they want to tear the union apart.

Big business is working with the government to sow the seeds of dissent at a time when we need unity. We need solidarity more than ever in our history. Not just our history but the history of the working man in America.
Yes.
You want to be a part of this fight?
Yes I do.
You want to be a part of this history?
Yes I do.
Can you be in Chicago tomorrow? Russell pushes the envelope on the table toward Frank.
For a minute there, I thought it was Patton.

Go to Chicago.  Speak to Joey Glimco at Local 777.  You’ll be working in Public Relations. Frank and Joey Glimco climb out of one of the cars. They, and several other men enter the back door of the building -
They are seated on a white tile counter draped in towels. Glimco is smoking a fat cigar in the steam-filled room.
You’re only here because Jimmy’s getting screwed. It’s the Seafarers Union trying to sign up the same non-union cab drivers we are.  Lesbians, a lot of them, for some reason.

This is what we have to deal with, how to get these drivers to join us rather than Paul Hall’s union. He’s bullshitting people that he can get a better contract than Jimmy. Frank walks over to the woman’s cab, opens the door and hot-wires it.
You understand, you’re here because nobody knows you or what the fuck you’re doing.
Jimmy has Daley’s cops’ okay on this.  They won’t help us push but they’ll make sure nobody stops us.
This is a lot of work.
Have you thought about using candy? Joey just looks at him, not sure what he’s saying.
One thing about Jimmy, never make him wait.  You have a meeting with him, get there on time.  Get there early.  I can’t stress this enough.  He goes by time. Joey taps at some watermelons.
We should get going then.
The other thing about him is he doesn’t drink. Imagine that? He’s the head of all the truck drivers in the world and don’t drink. He won’t even let you drink around him.  He calls it idiot juice.
The other thing about him - he doesn’t like watermelon. Joey pours a fifth of rum into the hole in the watermelon.
(excited) You shoulda seen them sink right in the water. One after the other. I’ll bet this morning, when they went looking for their cabs, they didn’t know what hit them.
Sinking the cabs. Great idea Joey.
It wasn’t my idea. It was Frank. Hoffa looks at Frank, impressed.
It’s not complicated. You just push.

He just took over the pier. They did exactly what he said. (gobbles up watermelon slice) I never seen a guy walk through a crowd like he does and he doesn’t touch a single person! I’m not kidding. I swear. Guys who didn’t even know him, never saw him before in their lives, still got out of his way. I’m telling you it was like “the parting of the waves” - like Moses! Hoffa looks over at a clearly mortified Frank listening to Glimco’s excessive praise.
(to Joey) You need him to stay another couple of days?
Yeah. We still got some dribs and drabs. Glimco hands Frank a slice of rum-laced watermelon.
(curious) You two sure like watermelon.

Everybody has to be united in the same direction, or there’s not progress for the worker, Frank. You saw it firsthand. To me those guys ain’t union. They’re like Nazi collaborators. Operating behind our lines. You were in the war. You know what I mean.
I do.

Good! Jimmy gets up in his pajamas and goes into his bedroom leaving the door open.  Frank arranges the pillows on the cot. He looks into the bedroom and sees that Hoffa is already sound asleep. Frank stretches out on the cot but he’s fully awake.

Back in the 1950’s, Jimmy was already the president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters. The most powerful union man in the country. Still, he didn’t make me stay in his suite in Chicago because he liked me. He made me stay with him because he didn’t want me registering in my name at the hotel. By staying with him in the big suite, there was no proof I was even in Chicago. It’s all about secrets. Just like Whispers, except for Whispers it didn’t turn out so good.

After Chicago, Jimmy and I got close. Our wives hit it off and with Jimmy and Josephine’s kids mostly grown up, they got a kick out of our kids, especially Peggy. She and Jimmy fell for each other right away. Jo wants a snapshot of Jimmy and Peggy together.  As they pose for the picture -
Can you keep a secret?
Sure.
You know what I like even better than getting my picture took?
What?

To Peg, Jimmy wasn’t like Russ, or Skinny or even me. For one thing, Jimmy didn’t have a nickname like the “Razor” or “The Hunchback”. Also, to her, he was helping people make more money, live better lives. He wasn’t stomping on somebody’s hand. Jimmy really does love ice cream, dipping his spoon into his sundae and savoring its taste like fine wine.

“If you have it, a truck brought it to you.”  This is what Mr. Hoffa says, and it’s true.  He’s the president of the Teamsters Union with over a million members. They all support him because they now have steady jobs, great pay and a pension for when they retire. Frank sits in a chair off to the side at the head of the class. It’s his turn at career day. Peggy and Frank are both wearing gold and blue enamel “A Friend of Jimmy Hoffa” buttons written across a miniature trailer truck.
The Teamster Pension Fund had eight billion dollars in it and Jimmy had complete authority over every bit of it.
A bridge loan is all I’m asking.
I’m not pissing away my members’ pension dough on bullshit.
You won’t. You can’t. I’ve got Minksy’s follies. I’ve got the first topless act on the Strip.
I’m just asking for a golf course. Jimmy you know you’ve never lost a dime with me.
We would appreciate anything you can do to help Jake along on this.
One five is all I need for the completion bond.
Whatever you can do Jimmy. Hoffa waves at Bill.
(to Bill) Okay. Okay. Go to the bank. Gottlieb remains seated beaming as Bill and Frank leave the office.
And, because of Mr. Hoffa, workers have medical insurance for when they get sick and know that when they retire they’re not going to go hungry.

There was so much paperwork back then that Jimmy had to use an insurance company, run by his friend, “Red” Dorfman’s son, Allen, to process the loans. A title appears: Allen Dorfman, shot eight times in the head in a Chicago parking lot, 1979.
Russ and his friends used to get guys like Gottlieb million-dollar loans and then tack on a ten-percent finder’s fee.
I appreciate what he did. He’s okay. You make sure you thank Marteduzzo from me.
He’d be glad to hear that.

Back then, because the money was for gambling, a lot of snooty banks wouldn’t lend casinos money for construction. I’m serious. But without the regular banks, it was the Teamsters’ billion-dollar pension fund that stepped in and lent the money that built Las Vegas.
There was more business than anybody could handle.

Jimmy had to shove some of the deals off on to Josephine who had no idea she had twenty-two percent of a Florida land deal called “Sun Valley”, some charter fishing boats, and a ski lodge with its own mountain.

One of Jimmy’s clients was Sam “Momo” Giancana, who was friends with the Kennedys from back when Jack’s father made his fortune (alongside the Italians) as a bootlegger during Prohibition. The old timers worked with him. Momo - Sinatra - they all partied with the Kennedys. Momo and Kennedy even had the same girlfriend. Together. At the same time.
So it was easy for the Mob to help Joe Kennedy get his son elected president by making sure he won in Illinois.

In exchange, the new president was going to get Castro out of Cuba so our guys could get their casinos and race tracks and shrimp boats in Havana back. TV NEWS IMAGES - ELECTION NIGHT & RESULTS Kennedy vs Nixon. Election night shows tight race. The next day, Nixon’s press secretary reads the concession letter to Kennedy.
The Italians wanted Kennedy the Irishman as President... and they got him. On TV, Jack Kennedy goes up to stage to make his victory speech.
Jeezuschrist! God damn Kennedys.
Jimmy, please, the kids.
Why? They’re gonna have to learn. We’re going to war.
I told you, you can’t trust a millionaire’s kids. As Jack makes his speech, a camera finds Robert Kennedy.
Especially that miserable little sonofabitch. ... and all the bullshit problems he’s already put me through.
Are you saying you don’t remember doing any favors for Johnny Dio or you don’t remember the conversation?
I’m saying, to the best of my recollection, I must recall on my memory, I cannot remember.
Where did this twenty thousand dollars come from?
From individuals.
Which individuals?

Offhand, that particular amount of money I borrowed I don’t know at this particular moment, but the record of my loans, which I requested, I have, and out of all the moneys I loaned over this period of time I went into these ventures. Everyone looks at each other to see if that made any sense to them.
Even Russ did his part getting Kennedy elected, too.
For guys like Russ, it couldn’t have been better.
(hating to have to say it) Thank you.
So what’s the first thing Jack Kennedy does to repay Chicago for all their help?

He puts his crazy brother in charge of the Justice Department. And what’s the first thing Bobby does?  He goes after not just Jimmy - which in a way you could understand - Jimmy hated the Kennedys so much he gave Nixon a half a million in Teamster cash. They were the only union to back Nixon - but Bobby also goes after Giancana and all the other guys who put his brother in the White House.

Everybody was sure everybody’s phone was bugged.  I mean you couldn’t say any names on the phone.  Everybody was “your friend” or “our friend,” whether they were your friend or not. Even when you talked about Bobby Kennedy.  He was “our friend”.

It really got much worse when Bobby became Attorney General. When he ran the McClellan Committee he held lots of bullshit hearings, but he couldn’t put anybody in jail.  Now, he was the Attorney General and he could send anybody to jail, and, no question Jimmy was at the top of Bobby’s hit list. He even set up a special “Get Hoffa Squad” where he had his own guys from the FBI and IRS working around the clock. Their only job was trying to put Jimmy Hoffa in jail. I’m serious. That’s all they did.

(slams phone) I’m working with a room full of fuckin’ idiots. You pricks! You motherfuckers put Johnny O’Rourke’s kid on as a “general organizer” for thirty-six grand at the same time you let him sell insurance to his father’s locals. Don’t you know I’m under the gun? I’ve got that Kennedy cocksucker sticking his nose up my ass and you let this shit happen in public.  You dumb motherfuckers trying to put me away? Frank turns and leaves the office.
Tell me now so I can kill you worthless fucks right here.
I could see it was getting to him. He was acting crazy. He was not the same Jimmy. He was vicious. It was really hard just being around him. Hoffa sees Frank leave. Stops.
Where you going?
I quit. You ain’t calling me a motherfucker!
What’s the matter with you! That don’t apply to you.
Then let me know that. They wanna take what you’re saying-- they can take it.  Not me.
But I said it don’t apply to you.
You got a problem pull me aside. Don’t insult me and then say it don’t apply to me.
(walks Frank back toward office) Okay. Okay. Come on. You know me better that.
In the end, I had to stick by him. I knew the bullshit he was going through.
Russ, I don’t know how Jimmy’s running the union with Bobby and the FBI up his ass all the time. He’s going crazy.
Tell Jimmy I’m sorry for his troubles, but if worse comes to worst, the old timers know the father. They talk... and they could straighten things out.
But he can’t understand why you guys helped the Kennedy pricks get elected in the first place. It don’t make sense to him.
Jimmy don’t have to know everything. You understand? Sometimes it’s better.
Yeah.

He’s too emotional. He gets caught up in bullshit like some guy being late. Who gives a shit? He misses the big picture. BUFALINO (CONT'D) 53(whispers) Like Cuba. Like getting us back in Havana. Like getting us back the casinos. Like getting rid of that Castro sonofabitch.
Jeezus!
They had a word with the old man. And he had a word with his son, and he let Jack know, you know, who he fuckin owes.
So, I want you to go see Phil at Milestone Hauling.  He’s gonna have a rig for you.
You take it, and you drive it down to Baltimore to this concrete plant on Eastern Avenue.  You can’t miss it, it’s the only one there.

A guy will meet you there.  A fairy named Ferrie. Dave Ferrie, whose alopecia has him wearing a homemade reddish wig, drawn eyebrows and makeup, directs Frank to back his rig up to where some army trucks are parked.

You’ll pick up some things and he’ll give you some paperwork for the load in case you get stopped. Frank watches some Maryland National Guardsmen transfer weapons, ammo, and uniforms from their trucks to his.
Drive the truck down to Florida. That’s where you’ll leave it.  A dog track outside Jacksonville.
A guy with big ears named Hunt will meet you there and give you a car to get you back to Philly. As the guy gives Frank the keys to a car, Frank regards his ears.  They don’t look so big.
What are you looking at?  You looking at my ears?
I ain’t looking at your ears.
I had an operation, so there’s no need for anyone looking at my ears anymore.
I ain’t looking at your ears. Big Ears walks away.  Frank climbs into the car and watches as a bunch of Cubans begin unloading the weapons and ammo from the truck he just drove down.
A counter-revolutionary coup led by Cuban exiles and backed by the Central Intelligence Agency, failed to unseat the island’s Communist dictator, Fidel Castro...
It was a disaster. Kennedy was supposed to send in planes for cover but he pulled back and a lot of Cuban guys got killed on the beach. Castro fulminates making an anti-American speech on TV.
Just like I predicted. Right after they fuck up Cuba, Boobie starts coming after me and the union. He’s looking for some cheap publicity. That’s what he’s doing.
It’ll blow over, Jimmy.
(annoyed) What’s the matter with you? It’ll never blow over. You think they’re ever gonna forget the money I gave Nixon? Never! Hoffa sweeps the subpoenas off his desk.
Jimmy, please, calm down. Some of the old timers are trying to reach the old man Kennedy now. He’s supposed to be sick, but...
(interrupts) Are you nuts?  The old man ain’t “sick”. He just had a stroke. He’s useless. He turned into an eggplant.
Oh shit! You can’t blame anybody for that.
I can! I blame his kids. The two of them. They did it.
- They gave their own father the stroke. I know it.
Everybody started thinking the same thing: Maybe Jimmy was right about the Kennedys in the first place.
Where are you going?
To work.  Go to bed.
We’re gonna get through all this legal bullshit garbage. Little “Boobie” Kennedy can’t do a thing to us because we’re the biggest, best and most honest union in the country. Crowd cheers.
Plus we have the strongest and most loyal members... Audience cheers.
... the greatest shop stewards and headbreakers -- ah, I mean Education Committee... Audience laughs.

... and with Frank Fitzsimmons, my Executive Vice President, having my back... (points to Fitz on dais) Right Fitz? FRANK FITZSIMMONS, 53, a bloated man raises his large scotch on the rocks to the cheering crowd.
You gave Fitz a nice “hello” tonight. I hope he deserves it.
Why?  Wadda ya mean?  What’s wrong with Fitz?
Nothing, Jimmy. I don’t mean it as a knock on the guy.
Yeah? Tell me.
Sure, the guy’s loyal. He’s even a nice guy, but he’s not too sharp. You know, he plays a lot of golf.
But that’s who you want for a number two. A nice guy. Not dumb, but somebody you can have walking behind you without getting knifed.
Maybe you’re right, Jimmy. That makes sense.

I may have faults, but being wrong isn’t one of them. I can sleep like a babe with Fitz. It’s the Little Guy I have to worry about. A song with the lyrics “You’re my boy, Tony Pro, We’re all yours” begins as -
The Little Guy was Tony Provenzano. A capo in a big New Jersey crew and the president of Local 560 in Union City, New Jersey. The song continues over -

You turl - you work - while the corporation kings - and princes of industry - with their vast - expense accounts - and salary - and lugerous yachts - make vast donations - to politicians - yes - who have dedicated themselves - to our - destruction.
Down with them!  Down with them!
Pro and Jimmy came up together and were close -

He’s out of control. He’s got a hand in everybody’s pocket. He’s shaking down the trucking companies right and left. He’s threatening people. I mean, once in awhile, okay, but all the time? It’s drawing attention.
I didn’t need Jimmy to warn me about Tony Pro.
What did I need to know? As Castellito settles on a station and sits back, SALLY BUGS, in the back seat, loops a nylon rope around Castellito’s neck and strangles him -

The man had Sally Bugs strangle Tony Castellito just because Castellito was coming up big in the union. Pro was so worried about the guy that after he had Sally Bugs strangle the guy, he had Sally stick him in a tree shredder.
That way there’d be no competition, not even from the grave.
Guys like that give unions a bad name.  Something’s got to be done.
Him being him, that could be tough.
No. No. I don’t want that.  I mean getting working guys who know the union, card-carrying teamsters like you and me, to start running to take over some of the locals.
He’s not going to like that.

So what? I’m the president. I run the union. All I need is some guys who know their way around and know how to handle themselves. That’s all. (Hoffa claps Frank’s shoulder) That’s why I want you to run for president of Local 326. Frank is stunned by Jimmy’s belief in him.
You’re like family to me, Frank. You, Irene, the girls. Lovely Peggy. But that’s not why I’m doing this. I’m not giving you anything you didn’t earn.
I don’t know what to say.
Say you’ll do it.  That’s all you’ve got to say. (whispered joke)
Plus, I can guarantee you’re gonna win.
I’ll do it.
Good. Frank watches as Jimmy’s head hits the pillow and within seconds is asleep.

That’s okay, I don’t need that. I just came over to introduce myself.  Frank Sheeran.  The new President of 326. The owner, surprised, puts the envelope back in the desk and tentatively shakes Frank’s hand.
What can I say - Hoffa took me out of a meat truck and put me in the union. He gave me my start, gave me my first charter, gave me my first union.
If they can prove you stole from them what they’re going to want is names.  Would you give them names to keep from going to jail?
No.
Good.  The lawyers will take care of this.  You got nothing to worry about. The truck driver gets up to shake Frank’s hand.

Your Honor, Mr. Hoffa was advised by counsel that it was perfectly legal for his wife to be part owner of a trucking business. Still, when the McClellan Committee challenged its legality, she immediately withdrew from the company. Among the spectators, and there aren’t that many beyond some print journalists, is a young man in a raincoat.

This should have been the end of the matter. There has been no indictment secured against my client in thirteen grand juries. The nut in the raincoat walks down the aisle toward the defense and prosecution tables -

Your Honor, this is an example of a personal vendetta against my client and his family by a frustrated Justice Department and Attorney General, Robert Kennedy - The nut pushes open the gate, pulls out a gun, points it at Jimmy, who rushes him, grabs him.  The gun - a pellet gun - goes off and everyone scrambles for cover as Jimmy wrestles the guy to the floor. Jimmy’s adopted son/bodyguard, Chuckie O’Brien - who looks Italian because he is - jumps over the railing and beats the guy in the head until the marshals get there and take over.  Jimmy is thrilled with Chuckie -
(raises Chuckie’s arm) This is my boy.  I raised this kid. (calmly to crowd) Remember. Always charge a guy with a gun and run away from a guy with a knife.
I know it sounds crazy, but I got a message from a higher power telling me to shoot Jimmy Hoffa. The camera flashes.
I was wondering if you and Ed Partin might be able to come down here.  There’s a lot of nuts in Nashville.
This one’s married to a state trooper. Jimmy takes a look at the surveillance photo of a woman juror on the table.
Oh, that’s good. (pause) We know anybody?
Mr. King, you’re a member of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, is that correct?
I respectfully decline to answer that under the protection afforded me by the Fifth Amendment.
All I asked you is are you a Teamster.
I respectfully decline to answer under the (protection) -
Fine.  Let me show you a photograph. Neal picks up an Exhibit photo of King at the patrol car.
I respectfully decline (to) -
I haven’t even shown you yet.
Oh, my God. They look up to the ice cream parlor staff gathering around a small TV behind the counter.  Jimmy cranes his neck but can’t see what’s on it.

What is it? He gets up to see what’s going on.  The attorneys and Chuckie and Frank follow him to the counter and see on the TV that John Kennedy has been shot in Dallas.  Frank is stunned.  The ice cream parlor workers and patrons start crying.  Jimmy and his attorneys don’t.
Mr. Hoffa, will you be attending the president’s funeral?
I wasn’t invited.
You don’t have to be invited. A million Americans will be there.
In that case, I need to check my schedule. Jimmy continues toward his waiting car, trailed by the news crew.
If you were to go, and were asked to speak, what would you say?
I’d say Bobby Kennedy is just another lawyer now. Jimmy looks up and sees that like all the other flags in the nation, the flag above Teamsters’ Headquarters is at half-staff.
(into the building) Sonofabitch.
Jimmy was right. Almost. After the assassination, Bobby’s own vendetta against everybody stopped.
But the prosecutors just kept coming. A year after Dallas, while Bobby was running for the New York Senate, the government still brought a jury tampering and fraud case against him.
Mr. Hoffa, most defendants who stand before this court for sentencing have either violated the property rights or personal rights of other individuals.
You stand here convicted of having tampered with the very soul of this nation.

You know, everybody likes to shop in your store but your son is “s’feigatta.”  He’s acting wild. You can't control him, you know, there’s nobody's going to want to come into your shop anymore.  And that’s not good for you and it’s not good for me, it’s not good for anybody.  You gotta, you gotta, take control of this kid.
Jimmy set it all up. Fitz was running things alright, but that was for show. Fitz got his orders from Jimmy through Bill and Allen Dorfman who ran Jimmy’s loans.
Where is he?  He’s late. Bill and Dorfman look at the ceiling. Finally Frank “Fitz” Fitzsimmons comes in and sits down next to Bill and Dorfman, taking a phone.
Sorry I’m late. We’ve got a lot going on.
Fitz’s main qualification was he was weak.  Jimmy could control him.  He liked to drink and play golf and that was about it.
As much as Jimmy was getting pissed at Fitz, everybody else liked him, cause they got things out of Fitz they could never get out of Jimmy. It’s what happens when you go away.

We like Fitz, but Jimmy’s got that ball busting Dorfman holding up loans that Fitzie already okayed. And that Dorfman’s one tough Jew. Which Frank takes as his order to get rid of Dorfman. He nods, he’ll take care of it.
So... uh...
No. No. Just put a firecracker up Dorfman’s ass. That’s all. Fitz will get the message. If you did it to Fitz, that lush would run to the Feds and screw everything up.
Fitz got the message.  He was terrified.  After that, anybody who wanted anything from the Pension Fund got it.
But in Lewisburg, Jimmy had the other thing to be concerned about: The Little Guy.
They got Pro for extortion and gave him seven years.  And by now things had got tense between him and Jimmy.

This is a work of art, Pete. Thank you. The kitchen inmate leaves to let him enjoy it.  Jimmy takes a bite, savoring the ice cream.  But then, spoiling the moment, Pro sits at the table with his tray of food, in a prison uniform now instead of pool attire.
I got to talk to you about a problem I got with my pension.
I know.
You know?  What do you know?
I know it’s a million-two and there’s a problem with it.
So you’ll look into it for me.
There’s nothing to look into. It’s what it is.
What is it?
You lost it.  You forfeited it when you came here.
Yours is forfeited, too?
No. Pro can’t imagine why his pension is gone and Jimmy’s isn’t, but Jimmy doesn’t elaborate, just eats his ice cream.  Eventually -
Yours is still there.  Your million-five or whatever it is.
Uh-huh.
We’re both sitting here.
We’re both sitting here for different things.  You’re sitting here for extortion.  I’m sitting here for fraud.
So?
So that’s the difference.
What’s the difference.
I didn’t threaten anybody, you did.
So what?  That makes no sense.
It does if you think about it.
It doesn’t, but I don’t want to debate.  Just do something about it.
There’s nothing I can do.
There’s always something you can do.
It’s Federal law.
I don’t care.  You can still do something about it.
I can’t.  What can I do.
You can get me my fuckin money.
How?
Some other way.
What way.
The same way you got your money.
I earned my money.
You’re here for fraud.  You stole money.  I stole money.  Okay, in a different way.  Fine.  Still.  I want what I’m owed.
You people.
What?
What?
What did you say?
I can’t help you.
You people, you said.  What does that mean, you people.
I’m done talking about this.

You people? Jimmy ignores him.  Eats his ice cream like Pro’s not there.  Suddenly Pro lunges across the table, and grabs him.  They tumble to the floor and fight until the guards get there to break it up.
With Bobby gone, Ramsey Clark got upped to Attorney General.

Public safety will not be found in wiretapping. Security is to be found in excellence in law enforcement, in courts and in corrections - not wiretapping. Nothing so mocks privacy as the wiretap and electronic surveillance. They are incompatible with a free society.
So in your judgment, the enactment of this bill will in no way affect your department’s war on organized crime?
That’s correct. Cheers erupt, glasses are lifted, the mobsters shouting ‘To Pamsey,’ and, ‘We love you, Pamsey.’
You know what this means.  We can speak English on the phone again.
That crazy bastard thinks he can do that right there in Columbus Circle in front of 5,000 people and get away with it? That’s not right. You hear me Frankie?
He was right. Who else runs around with show business people like he’s Errol Flynn, getting his picture in the papers, drawing attention to everybody.
He was known downtown as “Joey the Blonde”, but everybody, especially the newspapers, called him “Crazy Joe”.
Mr. Gallo, do you have an opening statement?
(looking down at the carpeting) Yeah.  This rug would be great for a crap game.
Right then, you knew it was all gonna fall apart.

He went against everything and he didn’t give a damn. Growing up, he kidnapped his own bosses. I don’t even know how he lived after that. When he went away he recruited black guys instead of his own kind, and when he got out, nobody knew what he was doing or who he was doing it with.
You don’t like what he’s doing? Say something... As Joe Colombo gets up to speak at the podium, a black man walks up and shoots him in front of his family, and is in turn shot by Colombo’s men.
... and see what happens.
Who does that? I tell you who does that. Nobody. Like him and Oswald, that’s it. And even in Dallas it was just Jackie there, not the kids.

...That’s how I get hired. I work everybody. I work Jews. I work Blacks. I work Gypsies. I work Italians. (seeing Gallo) Uh oh! (points) Not those Italians. (waves) Hiya! Joey! Hiya! Cent’anni! L’Chaim! Au Salud! (aside to crowd) I was told to be very careful of what I said. Gallo feigns anger and grabs a champagne bottle from a bucket and pretends to throw it.
(hands in prayer) No! Please. It’s okay, Joey, I got the money. Don’t shoot me. Madonna Mia. Maaa! Maaaaa! Gallo laughs and puts the bottle back.
(waves shyly) Happy birthday, Joey.
Hey Russ, (taps Russell’s pin) What’re you doing with that? You really believe in that bullshit league?
Joey, that’s nothing to talk about here.
What?
He’s a boss.
(laughs) So he’s a boss. So am I a boss. We’re all supposed to be brothers.
Joey, let’s not have a beef. Gallo walks off.  Russell looks at Frank looking at Joey.
For something like this you want two guns: The one you intend to use, and a backup. Frank regards the guns while the man who gathered them - red-haired John Francis - waits.

You want something with more stopping power than a .22. (moves the .22s aside) You certainly don’t want a silencer.  You want noise to send the witnesses running so they’re not looking at you. (moves the silencers aside) But not the noise a .45 makes that you could hear in a patrol car blocks away. (moves the .45s aside)
The cops call a .32 a woman’s gun because it’s easier to handle and doesn’t do the damage a .38 does, but it does enough. He picks up a .32 and a .38.
It would be late so the tourists from Idaho would be in bed.  And being in Little Italy would relax him. We - our POV - find and enter Umberto’s Clam House -
It was his birthday, so he’d be there with his wife and kid, which in this case, is the point.  They should have to see what it’s like. A waiter comes past with plates of spaghetti with clam sauce.
He’d have some champagne in him, which would slow him down a little. The POV finds the only empty table, a reserved card on it.
His bodyguard would be with him, and he himself might be carrying too, but it’d probably be in the wife’s purse.
You never got a lot of advance notice.  And all you knew was your part of it, since three people can keep a secret only if two of them are dead.
John the Redhead only knew he was going to drop me off, circle the block, and pick me up.
You want to take out the body-guard first.  Not kill him, just disable him.  You got no argument with him, so not in the face or chest. The Gallos and the bodyguard disappear into Umberto’s.
Sometimes with something like this you want to go to the bathroom first. John Francis pulls the car to the curb a block away. Frank gets out and the car pulls away.
It gives you a chance to make sure nobody followed you in.  It also gives you a chance to make sure nobody’s in the bathroom you have to worry about. Frank walks toward Umberto’s Clam House.
It also gives you a chance to go to the bathroom.  You don’t want to be uncomfortable. Frank opens the Mulberry Street door of Umberto’s -
But I went before and in a place this small, this late, you may as well just get to work.
Peggy, let’s go. Frank turns and sees Peggy, now about 22, behind him. Neither says anything about the news report or anything else.  She just leaves.
What can I say. The guy organized a prison. Give him six more months in there and he would have got them a pension plan.
The first thing I’m going to do is register with the Federal Probation Office, as I’m required to do.  Then I’m going down to Florida with my wife to get some sun.
Any plans after that?
Yeah.  Take back control of my union.
And the first thing I did was pick us up some chili dogs from Lums, which Jimmy loved almost as much as ice cream. Frank watches as his order is being cooked.
The secret is they steam them in beer. There’s not a better hotdog in America.
What am I going to do with Fitz. He tosses the newsletter to Frank.  A cover photo shows Fitzsimmons accepting some award.
He actually thinks he runs things? I appointed him!  He didn’t win any election!  Now he thinks he’s somebody?  Accepting fuckin awards? Jo comes over with her lunch to join them.
He’s very popular with certain people.
Of course he is!  He loans money to every goombah who asks. If the banks did that - can you imagine? - we’d have a financial crisis.
It don’t matter. You run against Fitz and you win hands down.
You’ve got the Southwest and Central locals locked up. All you need is enough votes in the Northeast and you can win it all.
(to Jo, offering her a chili dog as Hoffa continues to talk) Sure you don’t want one?
No. No thanks.
Yeah, I just can’t believe I’ve got to go to that prick Tony Pro to get them. Frank nods, but his silence says something.
What.
Like I said, Fitz is popular.
Wiseguys don’t run this union!
With Fitz, they do.
But once you’re back as President you can fire anybody, right? You can even fire Tony Pro.
That’s right.
You can even watch him clean out his desk so he doesn’t steal the pencils.

(to Frank) See that. Everybody thinks she’s the nice one and that I’m the bad guy. (kisses her cheek) It’s just the opposite. I’m the nice guy and she’s the killer. I hate I gotta deal with that cocksucker - he’s fucked everything up.
Tony Pro attacking Jimmy over the ice cream in the prison cafeteria - And right back here, to the CONDO -
I know that cocksucker is campaigning for Fitz on the sly.
It’s because of his pension.
Because of the pension he doesn’t deserve.
He still got a lot of votes over there.
Because of me!  I gave him that power!  Now I got to make peace with the cocksucker?  I gotta ask him to endorse me?  I hate the idea of that.
Without Pro’s locals, Fitz loses.
There’s no doubt about that. Jimmy tries to picture sitting down with Pro, and it’s enough to ruin his otherwise nice Lum’s lunch.
If I sat down with him, would you come along?
Of course.
Fuck it.  Let’s go.
Let’s give him a few more minutes.
This isn’t right.  You don’t do this.  You don’t make a man wait.
I know.

The only time you do is when? When you want to say something. When you want to say, Fuck you. That’s the only time. Frank nods.  They wait, Jimmy getting madder by the second. Finally, a white Cadillac pulls up out front and Pro, wearing shorts and a short-sleeve shirt, comes in with his cousin-in-law ‘Tony Jack’ Giacalone, who, unlike Pro, is wearing enough clothes to conceal a piece, and join Jimmy and Frank at the table.
Can you believe this weather? People are freezing to death in New York and look at us.  It’s 80 outside.  It’s perfect.  Why we don’t live here year-round is what I want to know.
It’s summer.
What?
It’s summer.  People aren’t freezing to death in New York.
In my mind it’s always 8 degrees in New York.  I’m making a point. Jimmy regards Pro’s casual attire and his tan.
This is how you dress for a meeting?
(re: Hoffa’s clothes) This is how you dress in Florida? In a suit?
For a meeting, if it’s Florida or Timbuktu.  And you’re late.
What?
You’re late.
There was traffic.
I’ve never been late for a meeting in my life.
(to his cousin-in-law) Wasn’t there traffic?
There was.
I’ve never waited for anybody who’s late more than ten minutes.
I’d say fifteen.  Fifteen is right.
No.  Ten.
I don’t think so.  Ten is not enough.  You have to take traffic into account.
That is taking traffic into account.  That’s why it’s ten.
I still say fifteen.
Ten.
Fine.  We disagree on that.
More than ten is saying something. Are you saying something to me.
I’m here.  That says what it says. What can I do for you? Jimmy can barely think straight as mad as he is about Pro being late, but eventually collects himself.
I want to ask you for your endorsement (for) -
Wait, before you tell me, let’s get the other thing straightened out.
I can’t do anything about your pension.  Not with Fitz in there. With Fitz there, you should talk to Fitz about it.
I did.  He says he’ll take care of it. No questions asked. You wouldn’t do that, but he will. I meant the other thing.
The other thing.
You know.
I don’t know.
Your apology.
My apology.  For what.
For what you said when you were sitting there eating your fucking ice cream like some fucking king. That was an ethnic slur - “you people.” Jimmy just looks at him.  Then -
I’ll apologize for that - after you apologize for being late - you mother fucking wop cocksucker. Now Pro just looks at Jimmy while Frank shakes his head wearily.  Eventually -

I’ll apologize for being late - after I kidnap your granddaughter, rip her guts out and send them to you in a fuckin envelope. Jimmy goes for him.  Frank and Tony Jack try to pull them apart - like the guards did in the prison cafeteria - but, just like then, it isn’t easy.
You think Russell would do something about the Little Guy?
That would be complicated.
I know, but maybe you could talk to him.  Have a conversation.  See what he says.
I don’t approve of what Pro said to Jimmy.  Who talks like that about a man’s grandchildren? That’s not right.
But Pro isn’t nobody, Jimmy knows that.  I’m not going to tell him what he can and can’t say.
He’s very upset, I understand.
I’m sure he is.  But Jimmy says things too he shouldn’t sometimes. Somebody should calm him down. Frank looks to Russell.
I don’t know what to tell him to calm him down.
I don’t know if it will calm him down but you can tell him I always liked him and won’t stand in his way trying to get his job back.
That doesn’t calm me down.  Not standing in my way is not the same as doing something about a fucking out of control lunatic.
He’s not nobody, The Little Guy.
He’s a cocksucker.  Fitz is a cocksucker.  I’ll deal with both these cocksuckers myself.
This used to be my office. Frank Fitzsimmons travels around the country to every goddamn golf course there is.  Who is he to run around with Nixon and the Attorney General?
He does this and collects a full-time salary.  How do you do that? There’s not enough hours in a day. I went to prison for fraud; this is fraud what he’s doing.
Fitz responded to Jimmy by sending a message to Jimmy’s old friend, Dave Johnson. As they near their 45-foot cabin cruiser, it suddenly blows up -
This is how Fitz says he wants Dave to step down so his son can run Local 299?  By blowing up Dave’s boat?  This is how I say no to Little Fitz.
This is how Big Fitz says he doesn’t like who I say runs the 299?
Firing my wife from her forty-eight-fucking-thousand-dollar-a year union job? Her hand shakes as she turns the key in the ignition, but the car doesn’t blow up.
Fine.  Fuck them all. Frank is a little distracted by the Watergate witness. E. Howard Hunt according to the TV chyron.
What’re you looking at.
It’s Big Ears.
What?  Who?  His ears don’t look so big.
Frank Fitzsimmons has sold this union out to his underworld pals.

The mob controls him, which means it controls our Pension Fund.  I’m talking about a billion dollars in low and no-interest loans this man has given to known racketeers for their illegal enterprises.  Not anymore.  It’s time the rats abandoned ship.
Is he serious?
He doesn’t mean any of this.
Maybe he got religion in prison.
He didn’t.
People do.  Remember Whispers. The other Whispers.
Not Jimmy. It’s all for the publicity. He’s running for office. He’s putting on a show.
I don’t know.  When I hear a thundering stampede I think of getting run over by hoofs.  Maybe he means what he says.
He’s campaigning. He’ll say anything.
I don’t care. I don’t like it. It’s no good. Talking like that. Maybe he should cash in that pension and spend more time with his grandchildren. Like the last time, Salerno looks to Frank.
Word should get back to him.
Who said that?
It doesn’t matter.  It was said.
Was it Russell?
No.
Was it the Little Cocksucker from the Miami Fiasco?
No.
Then who.
The other Tony.
Which other Tony?  They’re all named Tony.  What’s the matter with Italians - they can only think of one name.
Salerno. That Tony means something to Jimmy.  It gives him pause. But not enough to convince him to change what he’s doing.
I don’t care who said it, they’re not going to shut me up.  Somebody can tell him that.
He said that? (Frank nods) Before he says things like that, he should remember:  Crazy Joe liked to make a lot of noise too. Somebody should tell him that.
He said that?  This fuckin guinea said that?  That does it. I’m never retiring.  Somebody can tell him that.
I have, Jimmy.  Over and over.
Then there’s nothing more to talk about.  Let me enjoy my ice cream. Jimmy spoons at his ice cream.  Frank glances at the TV, though not really to watch it.  Eventually -
What.
What?
You’re thinking something.  What is it?
It’s not the right time.
What isn’t.
(pause) The Local’s putting together a testimonial dinner for me.  I was thinking of asking if you might present the award.
Who’s going to be there?
Everybody.
Tony, Tony, Tony and Tony.
(nods) Everybody from Downtown. Jimmy knows he won’t exactly be safe at a place with “everybody” there.
It’s not a good idea right now. I understand.

No, I don’t give a fuck who’s there.  They’re not going to keep me away from your big night. These cocksuckers.  You deserve this.  I’d be honored.  I’ll be there. Jimmy thinks about it a moment longer, then glances to the TV.  John Dean testifying, his wife sitting stoically behind him.
Good looking broad, that Mo Dean.

We’ve got a great turnout for Frank tonight, because Frank’s a man with a lot of friends. From his army buddies who fought with him in Italy under General George Patton, to the drivers, national organizers, business agents, local presidents, joint council chairmen and regional trustees. Tonight, we’re all “Friends of Frank’s”, like NAACP president, Cecil Moore; District Attorney, Emmett Fitzpatrick; Philadelphia Mayor, Frank Rizzo... As he continues introducing the dignitaries on the dais with Frank, a title comes up on screen - Roofers Union President John McCullough, shot six times in the head in his kitchen, 1980.
And of course, our featured speaker, James Riddle Hoffa. Meanwhile, outside, in the trees, we’ve got the FBI.
He’s not even the goddamn president and he’s holding up people’s loans.
We sure? How?
He’s using his pension fund trustees - his guys to hold back loans for a new hotel in New Orleans for Carlos and loans to build up Caesar’s on the Strip.
What about Fitz? He’s gotta be able to help.
The money comes through the trustees. They gotta sign off. They’re supposed to rubber stamp whatever Fitz says, except Jimmy’s got a couple of them to stop rubber stamping.
Son of a bitch.

He said to somebody, once Fitz is out and he’s in, he’s going to call in old loans.  Real estate, casinos, whatever it is, you don’t pay him the full thing and interest in two seconds, he’s taking them over.
He said that?
Who does he think he is, Castro? Hoffa can’t hear what they’re saying down there, but doesn’t shy from looking them in the eye when they look up at him.
I don’t understand why you’re doing this.  You don’t need the money.
It’s not about money.
Then I don’t understand what all this talk is about.
It’s my union.
I don’t know.  It seems maybe it’s about something else. Nothing from Jimmy.
Some people - not me - are a little concerned.  Some people - not me - feel you - might be -
Might be -
Demonstrating a failure to show appreciation.
I’m not showing appreciation?
Some people - not me - might think so.
I went to school for five fuckin years.  I didn’t name one fuckin name.
I know. Jimmy glances over to where Tony Pro is talking to Salerno at his table.
I had to sit there listening to that whining cocksucker from New Jersey when all I wanted was to eat my ice cream in peace.
I know.
This cocksucker shows up to a meeting fifteen minutes late in fucking shorts.  Who wears shorts to a meeting?
I know.
I’m not showing appreciation?
According to some people - not me.
Fuck them.  Nobody threatens Hoffa. As Jimmy walks away, everything in room slows down.  From the dais, Frank watches, more than a little concerned.
Jimmy shouldn’t have walked away first.  He should have let Russell walk away. Russell just stands there, looking after Jimmy, no doubt thinking the same thing.
Frank has devoted his life to this union.  As a driver, as an organizer, as a mediator - he’s been tireless in his service to the working men and women of this country.
He also holds a record you may not know, which I don’t think anybody will ever beat:  Most arrests on a picket line -  26 times in 24 hours - beating my record! The guests applaud and laugh.

I’ve known Frank a long time. I respect him.  I rely on him. He is a union man to his bones, and he’s my friend.  I’m honored to present this award - and this beautiful watch - to Frank Sheeran. Frank joins him at the podium as everyone applauds. Jimmy straps a gold diamond-encrusted watch on his wrist, pats him on the back, turns the microphone over to him.

Thank you, Jimmy.  Thank you all. Thank you to my wife Irene and my lovely daughters, Maryanne, Dolores, Connie - Peggy - for putting up with me all these years. Three of his daughters are smiling.  Peggy isn’t.

And to Jimmy. I can’t tell you what this means to me to get this honor from you. Jimmy’s the only guy to get the job done and I promise all my support and help to you, Jimmy. (mild applause) Russ bet me I was going to mess up my speech... so all I can say is, thank you all from the bottom of my heart. I know I don’t deserve all this tonight.  But I have bursitis and I don’t deserve that either. (laughs) See Russ, I didn’t mess up my speech. Everyone laughs.
Look at all these people who came out for you.  Even the mayor. I truly had no idea you were this strong.
It’s a free steak and an open bar.
No, they’re here for you, my friend. The camera flashes.
Couple more, please.
I’m sorry Pro’s here.
You have no control over that. The camera flashes.

I really do appreciate all the support you’ve given me, Frank. I mean it.  It’s not just words. I’m glad you’re on my side. Frank forces a smile for the photographer as the camera flashes again taking a photo of Frank with Jimmy, another with Cecil Moore, another with Mayor Rizzo, another with Jimmy’s kids.
I didn’t want to do this in front of everybody. He hands Frank a small jewelry box.  Inside it, Frank finds a gold ring with a gold coin on top.

Only three people in the world have one of these, and only one of them is Irish.  I have one. Angelo.  And now you. (pause) You know what this means. Frank does.  It’s as close to a made-man any non-Italian will ever get.
I don’t know what to say.
Put it on.  Let’s see if it fits. Frank slips the ring on.  It fits.  Jerry Vale starts another song.
There’s something else. It just got out of hand with your friend. Some people have a serious problem with him. Talk to your friend. Tell him, it’s what it is. Frank isn’t sure he heard right.
It’s what it is?
Yeah. Talk to him.
I’ll do my best. You know yourself, Russ; he’s tough to talk to.
He’s got no choice. It comes from high up.
Jimmy’s pretty high up himself.
You’re dreaming, my friend.  If they can take out the President they can take out the president of a union. And, as it’s supposed to work, Russell walks away first.
I just spoke to Russell.  He just spoke to Tony.  He means what he’s saying.
Who?  Russell?
Tony.
Well, I mean what I say.  He can’t seem to get that through his fat fuckin Sicilian head. Jimmy notices how ashen-faced Frank looks.
Don’t look so concerned.
I’m a little concerned.
They should be concerned, not you.
They are.  They’re more than a little concerned.  There’s widespread concern.
Tony told Russell to tell me to tell you what it is. Jimmy looks at Frank a bit stunned finally.
They wouldn’t dare.
Don’t say that, Jimmy.

Something funny happens to me, I got stuff ready to go. To the press. To the right people. They do something to me, something is gonna be done to them, and those guinea motherfuckers know that. They know I know things that I know. They know I know things they think I don’t know.
Jimmy, what am I supposed to do. I got to go back and tell the old man - what.  That you’re still not listening to him?  He ain’t used to people not listening to him.
Neither am I. Frank has run out of ways to make him see.
Then I don’t know, you should maybe keep some bodies around for protection.

I’m not going that route, they could go after my family.  You should keep some bodies around, they could go after you since you’re with me. Frank isn’t sure who he’s with anymore, so caught in the middle.
Tell Russ I got nothing but respect for him.  I would never hurt him.  But this is my union.
Jimmy leaves him to go to the Sheeran family table.
You know what I love, Peggy?
Ice cream.
More than ice cream.  You.  Let’s dance.
The wedding was all well and good, but the real point of our trip to Detroit was a peace mission.
I’m with the old man.  We’re driving up.  He hopes this thing can be worked out.
What’d he say?
He said let’s work this thing out.  Sit down after the wedding and work it out.
I’m not going to the wedding. Too many people I don’t like are going to be there.
We could do it at your place if you want.
At the lake, huh.
Or anywhere.
From day one I wanted to work this out.
I know.
From day fucking one.
I know.
Just you two, right?  Not the Little Guy.
Of course the Little Guy.
No.  Just the three of us.
There’s no point just the three of us.
I’m not sitting down with that cocksucker.
It’s time to sit down, Jimmy. Everybody says so.
Not with him.
You’re making me work hard.
Just us. Jimmy hangs up.  Frank lets himself out of the booth. Russell comes over unwrapping a candy bar.
What’d he say?
He’s thinking about it.
That’s good.  That’s progress. You want half of this Milky Way?
You should give Jimmy another call, don’t you think?  See if he’s thought about it.
When you getting in?
Tomorrow morning.
Good.  I changed my mind about the other thing.
You did?
I’m meeting with the Little Guy tomorrow afternoon.
With the Little Guy.
Tony Jack set it up.
With the Little Guy.  Where?
In public, where do you think. The Red Fox.  On Telegraph.  You know it?
Tony Jack is Pro’s cousin.
They’re all fucking cousins, what are you going to do.  But Jack’s okay.  I talked with him several times after the Fiasco-In- Miami.
I’d feel better if I was there.
So would I, that’s why I asked when you’re getting in.
What time’s the meeting?
2:30, and he better not be late. Or wearing fuckin shorts.
The Red Fox.
On Telegraph.  I’ll be there at 2. So you should be there at 2.
I’ll be there at 2.
Good. Jimmy hangs up.  Frank hangs up, a little puzzled about Jimmy’s change of heart.  Walks back to the patio table.
What’d he say?
He’s going to meet with Pro.
That’s good.
Tony Jack arranged it.
That’s good. And that’s it.  No other comment.  Which Frank finds a little odd after all that’s gone on with this.
Maybe Jimmy was counting on Pro to act like Pro so Tony Jack could see Jimmy being reasonable and Pro being unreasonable like in Miami, and tell Salerno.

Or maybe this wedding really was bringing everybody together. There’s a knock on the door.  Russell and Carrie - dressed nicely, too - Russell holding the bag with a loaf of prosciutto bread in it.  As they all leave -
Whatever it was, you’d think Russell would’ve asked when the meeting was, where it was, whether he was supposed to come or not. Something. The door closes.  We remain in the empty motel room.
But he didn’t ask anything.
By the way, we got a little change in plans.  We’re going to hang around here tomorrow morning and drive up in the afternoon.
I told Jimmy we’d be there in the morning.
I know.
That I’d be at the meeting with him and Pro.
I know. Frank does okay not showing it, but is reeling from Russell telling him he’s not going to let him be with Jimmy at the meeting.

We did all we could for the man, Cheech. Russell looks to Frank for a nod that he understands, but Frank doesn’t nod.  Russell swirls the salad dressing in the jar around and dips a finger in to taste it.
Don’t call him.
Morning.
Good morning.
How’d you sleep?
Fine.
Want some Total?
Okay. Russell prepares him a bowlful.
We’re going up to Port Clinton today.
I thought we were staying here.
The women are staying here.  We won’t be gone long.  Three hours tops. They sit with their cornflakes.  Russell eats his.  Frank lets his get soggy.
What’s in Port Clinton?
A plane.
A plane. (Russell nods) To where?
Detroit. This isn’t making any sense to Frank.
We’re going to Detroit now?

You’re going to Detroit now. Then you’re coming back.  Then we’ll take our time driving up there.  Nice leisurely drive. And fuckin cigarette breaks. Frank has no idea what he’s talking about, but doesn’t like it, whatever it is.
I got to put you into the thing, Frank.  Otherwise you’d never let it happen.  And it’s gonna happen. Russell looks at Frank like a father to a son.

Either way, Jimmy will be gone, but this way, and it’s only out of respect for me they agreed to it by the way, everything will be okay for you and Irene, because you’re with me. He eats his cornflakes.
Hi, Frank. Sally has a matte-knife in his hand and uses it to cut some linoleum he’s laying out on top of the wood floor of the entry.

Sally. Frank surveys the entry.  Then walks into the adjacent living room, glimpsing as he goes two young Italian guys in the kitchen down the hall, playing cards.  Sally Bugs comes over, parts the living room blinds and looks out.
Chuckie’s late.
Jimmy’s son Chuckie, his foster son, he was in the thing, too, but didn’t know it. Sally Bugs sees a car pulling to the curb.
Is that him? It’s a maroon Mercury Marquis with just the driver in it. Frank nods.

All Chuckie knew, he was picking up one of Pro’s guys and me and we were all picking up his dad at the Red Fox for a meeting. Chuckie gets out of the car.  Leans against the car, waiting, wearing a wide-collared paisley shirt and gold chains.
He was in it, as you say, stupidly.
I’m Sally.
Hi.  Hi, Frank.
Chuckie.

Let’s go.  I don’t want your father yelling at me for being late.  You can sit in front, Frank. Frank doesn’t want to sit in front.  Sally Bugs, we may recall, strangled that poor Teamster Treasurer in a front seat.  But Sally already has the car’s back door open and is sliding in.
The fuck is this?
What.
It’s wet back here.
I had a frozen fish I had to drop off to someone.
A fish?  The seat is wet from a fish?
Sorry.
I’ll sit back there.
No, no, no, it’s all right, you take the front. As Frank reluctantly climbs into the front passenger seat, Sally Bugs lays his handkerchief on the back seat and sits on it.
What kind of fish.
What?
What kind of fish.
I don’t know.  A fish.  To eat.
You don’t know what kind?
No.
Where’d you get it?
At a fish place. Frank checks his watch.  It’s 2:40.
Sorry I’m late.
Late?  What the fuck you even doing here?  Who invited you?
Hi, Jimmy.
Who the fuck are you?
I’m with Pro.

You’re with Pro.  You’re with this cocksucker who’s late again?  I’m not waiting for this cocksucker again.  He was supposed to be here at 2:30.  It’s 2:40.  I don’t wait for anybody more than ten minutes. Mother fucking cocksucker.
He’s at the house.
What house?
He’s with Russ.
He’s with Russ ... What the fuck is going on here?
Look who’s here. Jimmy leans down to see who’s in the passenger seat.
Hi, Jimmy.
Frank.  What the fuck’s going on here?  Where were you?  You were supposed to be here at two.  What is this?
Russell decided to come.  But not here.  He doesn’t know the place. It’s not comfortable for him.
McGee is here?  In Detroit?
To help straighten all this out. That changes things.  Jimmy relaxes a little.
We’ll bring you back after to get your car. Sally Bugs pushes open the back door for Jimmy to get in and the motion slows down -

No way in a million years Jimmy would ever get in a car with one of Pro’s guys in it ... unless I was in it, too.  Which is why I was in it.  I made it safe. The motion returns to normal as Sally Bugs taps the seat next to him.
There was a fish in here, but I cleaned it up.
What?
Chuckie had a fuckin fish in here, he doesn’t even know what kind, but it’s okay now, I wiped it up.
You put a fish in here?  In your car?
For Bobby Holmes.  Bobby likes fish.
I cleaned it up, Jimmy.  It’s all right.
You cleaned it up, the fuck you know about fish?  You ever caught a fucking fish in your life?
No.
Then you don’t know. Jimmy glances off to his own car, then back to Frank again as if to say, Promise me this is okay.  Frank nods.
It’s all right. Jimmy finally gets into the back seat next to Sally.
Chuckie, never put a fish in your car, you’ll never get the smell out.  Unless it’s wrapped up good.
I know. The Mercury pulls out of the lot.
Frank.  You couldn’t come by at 2:00 and tell me this?  I had to wait there forty minutes like a fuckin moron?
I came as soon as I got in.
You got in this morning.
No.  Russell had some business in Port Clinton this morning.

This morning.  Okay.  But it’s this afternoon.  All due respect to Russ but nobody could come over at 2:00 and tell me it was 2:30? 2:40?  At the very least? (like Sally’s not there) And who the fuck is Pro sending a fucking errand boy.
Sally’s not staying.
That’s right he’s not staying. But Pro sent him is the point I’m making, when he should’ve come picked me up himself. (to Sally) Can you even see out those glasses?
I can see, Jimmy.
You got your friend with you? Glancing back, he sees Frank touch the small of his back.
Good.  You never know with this cocksucker, with or without Russ there. He opens the front door and -
He knew right away what it was.
Just not my part of it.

Let’s get out of here, Frank. As Jimmy bumps past Frank to leave, grasping the knob of the door Frank just closed, Frank shoots him twice behind his right ear. He slumps to the floor.  Blood runs onto the temporary linoleum.  Frank glances down the hall to see if someone is going to come kill him now - which wouldn’t surprise him - but no one appears. Frank tries to open the front door but Jimmy’s body is against it.  He gently tugs Jimmy away from it, gets it open, wipes the .22 with a handkerchief and sets it on Jimmy, wipes the door knob, and leaves.
Still no word? Irene shakes her head no.  Frank pours himself a drink.
I should call Jo.
You haven’t called her yet? Frank shakes his head no.  Irene turns back to the TV report.  Peggy doesn’t.  She studies her father.
Why.
Why what.
Why haven’t you called her. The image of the family slows ...
