Maybe it was I looked hard instead of worried.  Or that I should have been rushing out to hurt somebody, and wasn’t. Whatever it was, she knew. The image returns to normal.
I’ll call her now. Peggy watches her father turn and head upstairs.
She stopped talking to me that day.  August 3rd, 1975.
She’s got a good job and lives outside Philly now but my daughter Peggy disappeared from my life that day.
Jo?  It’s Frank. (listens, nods) Whatever you need, anything I can do, I’m here. She’s crying now.  He puts the receiver to his head like it’s a gun ... then back to his ear.
It’s gonna be all right.  I’m sure he’s all right.
Anybody that says Jimmy was shipped in a 55-gallon drum to a dump in New Jersey or to the end zone in Giants Stadium never had a body on their hands.
It was no more complicated than that.
Everybody who ever had anything to do with Jimmy was hauled in and questioned.  And everybody took the Fifth, which is what you do.
On the advice of counsel, I respectfully decline to answer that question under the protection afforded me by the Constitution, on the grounds that my answer might tend to incriminate me.
Let me ask you this: What color is my pen?
On the advice of counsel, I respectfully decline to -

Still, everybody got indicted and convicted of one thing or another, just not for that. Nobody, as you know, even went to jail for that.  And nobody talked. Which is unusual since usually three people can keep a secret only when two are dead.
Bruno Denzetta and Marco Rossi got twenty years for squeezing cash out of a trucking company in exchange for labor peace.
Pro was convicted with them, but he was already back in school for that other matter I mentioned before -

That poor union Treasurer Tony Three Fingers who got more votes than Pro, which they finally got Pro on. As the nylon rope loops around the guy’s neck to strangle him, Coke bottle glasses on a face come into frame.
Sally Bugs, you recall, did that one.
One day he was seen walking into the Federal building.

That by itself isn’t a crime. Everybody gets called in there sometime.  But Sally - who knows better - didn’t tell nobody about it. Not a word to anybody. And then, you know, between one thing and another, it meant one thing:  He wasn’t going in there for lunch. Frank nods.  He knows he’s just been told what to do by not being told not to do it.
Hi, Sal.

Hi, Frank. Sally looks at John Francis, who he doesn’t know.  As he waits for an introduction, Frank shoots him twice in the head - one of the bullets shattering a lens of his thick glasses.  He hits the ground and John Francis fires three shots into Sally’s belly.  As they walk away -
It turns out Sally did tell somebody he had to go in there. They just forgot to tell somebody else.  So it was a bad hit.
Fat Tony Salerno they got on an income tax thing.  A little while after he was diagnosed with prostate cancer.
You know there’s a pork store in Walnut Creek, California, Jimmy. It’s right near where you live. You ever go there?
Russell got hooked for telling Jimmy “The Weasel” to strangle Jack Napoli over 25 grand of jewelry Jack took on credit and never paid for.
Only The Weasel flipped.  They called it Conspiracy to Kill a Witness, though it was Napoli who was clearly in the wrong.

They brought me up on bribery and labor racketeering charges and some other things - A title appears: Murder, Attempted Murder, Intimidation, Embezzlement, Arson Frank in the witness box where he’s been for awhile.

I’m going to say to you one time, I’ve listened to you, now you listen to me. I’ve worked for 44 years, and I never took one dime illegal off Boffa or nobody else. What you think don’t interest me. All I know is I paid him. What he does with the money is his business.
But all they got me for was blowing up the office of a crane company that fired two of my shop stewards for no good reason - The place blows up.
And for my Lincoln.

I bought it from Eugene Boffa, who leased truck drivers to freight companies and paid them substandard wages, skimming the difference. Frank peers through soapy windows of the car wash at his Lincoln as leather tongues shimmy and sway and push the suds around.

They said I paid under-market value for the car, and I had no receipts to prove otherwise.  They said the car was a bribe to let Boffa continue to pay his non-union wages. Frank watches the Lincoln as spray-hoses rinse it and the dryer blowers switch on.
I loved that car, but it wasn’t worth the eighteen years they gave me for it.

Russell had a stroke.  Fat Tony Salerno couldn’t control his urine anymore.  My arthritis that started in the foxholes of Anzio was eating at my lower back now, and I couldn’t feel much in my feet neither.  I needed a cane, but they won’t give you a cane in prison since you could use it as a weapon.  Neurontin helped a little but it also makes you loopy. Frank, who’s getting no younger himself, watches from the sidelines.
We were all falling apart in the freezing fucking cold.
You got it. Frank nods.  Takes grape juice and prosciutto bread from the bag and begins breaking it into pieces.  Eventually -
Jimmy was a nice man.  Nice family.  I didn’t want it to go that far.
I know. Frank pours two glasses of grape juice. Russell’s hand tremors a bit as he dips a piece of bread in the juice.
Where you going?
To church.
To what?
Don’t laugh, my friend, you’ll go too, the time comes. Frank watches Russell as his wheelchair rolls along the frozen ground.
Russell went to church.  Then he went to the prison hospital. Then he went to the graveyard.

I got out that October.  Irene died in December.  December 23rd. Lung cancer.  No surprise. Frank stands at his wife’s grave with three of his grown daughters, supporting himself on two aluminum canes like a polio victim. Peggy’s there, too, but stands apart from her sisters and father.  He looks at her, but she won’t look at him.
I got it.  I’m fine.  You stay here.
Peggy, don’t.  I just want to talk to you. She walks away from the counter toward the back.  Goes through a door and closes it.  The other customers look at Frank.
What do you want me to do about it?
Call her.  Tell her I want to talk to her.
Talk to her and tell her what?
I want to tell her I’m sorry.
For?
I know I wasn’t such a good father.  I tried to be.  I tried to protect her.  All of you.
From what? Now that he thinks about it, he’s not sure what.
You have no idea what it was like for us.  We couldn’t come to you with a problem because of what you’d do. We couldn’t go to you for protection because of the terrible things you’d do.
But I was just trying to keep you from getting hurt. Dolores regards him a moment.  He looks helpless. Hapless.  Hopeless.  Eventually -
No. No. You weren’t a bad father. That’s what he wants to hear, but by itself, it seems qualified, which it is.
We were just afraid of you.
I could sell you something for a lot of money but I’ll be honest with you:  It makes no sense going with anything more expensive than particle board for cremation. Will it be cremation?
Burial.
Okay, that’s going to be more.
That’s okay. Frank surveys the rows of caskets from his wheelchair, the orderly by his side.
Is it for a man or a woman?
It’s for me. His eyes settle on a metal one, green as the green on the Irish flag.
That one.
We're all terminal.  And sooner or later.  Everybody put here has a date when he’s gonna go. And I think... it could be... there's gotta be something somewhere.

There's gotta be something when you go cause how the hell did this whole thing start? What they taught you as a kid? People smarter than me can't figure it out. But there's gotta be something to it. So if there's something good... if it is... I want a shot at it. That’s why I would never go for cremation. It's so final. That’s the hardest part of anybody when they bury is when they go into the ground. Because it's so final. You know what I mean? If you go into a building. The building's there. Your crypt is there.  It has to be a metal casket and they have you in the room. And all that there.  It's just not as final - you're dead - but it's not as final. Frank stands before them, considering them.  There’s no good choice - or bad choice for that matter.  A girl from the office with a diagram on a clipboard waits for him to decide.  Doesn’t rush him.  Finally, he points.
That one, I guess.
I’m sorry but I have to direct you to my attorney Mr. Ragano if you want to talk about Mr. Hoffa - or any other matter for that matter.  I got nothing new to say.
He’s dead.
Who’s dead?
Your attorney, Mr. Ragano.
He’s dead?  Who did it?
Cancer. Frank didn’t know.

Everybody’s dead, Mr. Sheeran. Russell, Angelo, Salerno, Pro, Dorfman, Sal Briguglio.  But Mr. Hoffa’s children aren’t dead. They live with not knowing, and that’s hard to do.  You have children.  You know.  It’s time to say what happened. Frank actually seems like he might be thinking about telling them.  But then -
You seem like nice fellas.  And I appreciate you coming to see me. But I can’t help you.
Do you still remember the Hail Mary and Our Father?
Say it. See if I do.
Try it. (Frank hesitates) Should I say it?
You say it then (I’ll follow) -
Well if you say it, I’ll know whether you remember.
I go so far - “Hail Mary full of grace, Our Lord is with thee -
(prompting) Blessed art thou -
- amongst women -- That’s about as far as I go.
You want me to say it?
Yeah, why don’t you.
Hail Mary, full of grace. / The Lord is with thee / Blessed art thou among women / And blessed is the fruit of thy womb, Jesus - Frank joins in the prayer, saying it along with the Priest.
- Holy Mary, Mother of God / Pray for us sinners / Now and at the hour of our death. Amen.
Well, I say what I know - forgive me for not knowing the other half. The intention is there. Silence.
You feel nothing for what you did - (the killings)?  [Contrition talk]
No.
You don’t feel anything?

I know you’re supposed to feel something.  But I guess the fact that I’m here talking to you - that’s something... I guess. It’s a different world where I’m from. There are things you have to do. That’s the life you’re in. You give your word. You do the wrong thing you gotta pay - You don’t know...
So you don’t feel anything?
No, they deserved it.
You feel no remorse.
Water under the dam.
Nothing for their families.
I didn’t know their families. Except one... Silence as Frank regards the photo that’s now on top in his hands: One of Jimmy and Frank taken at Frank Sheeran Appreciation Night.
Did I have any choice?
If you had a choice, would you have done the same thing?
Let’s put it this way, if I didn’t do it, nothing was gonna change. They would’ve done it anyway. And then done it to me, too... What kind of man makes a phone call like that?
What do you mean?

That’s all I can tell ya. It kills Frank to keep looking at the photograph of Jimmy, but he forces himself to for several more moments. Nothing can dull the guilt he feels for what he did to Jimmy, and as the priest studies him, he thinks he sees something in Frank that was hidden before.  Not just remorse, but some faint remnant of humanity.
Would you like to pray now?
Yes.

God we come before you sinful and sorrowful, aware of what we have done and what we have failed to do. We ask you to help us see ourselves for who we are, just as you do, and we ask your forgiveness for anything that we might have done wrong, because we know that you are all good and all loving, and love us even when we fail.
This is my daughter Peggy. It’s the snapshot of Peggy and Jimmy at the miniature golf course.  The nurse gives it a perfunctory glance.
Is it. Frank nods to himself.
I don’t think I’ve met her yet.
She hasn’t been around much. The nurse cuffs his arm to check his blood pressure. And, just making conversation, like she does with all patients -
She’s your only child?
I have four daughters.
Really. Frank nods.  None of them have been around much. She glances down at the photo again.
Who’s that with her?
Who’s that?  You really don’t know? She takes a closer look at the picture.
That’s Jimmy Hoffa.

Oh... She clearly doesn’t know who that is.  Frank doesn’t bother telling her.  She puts her fingers to his wrist to check his pulse rate.  He looks at the next snapshot: Jimmy and himself at Appreciation Night.
You only know how fast time goes when you get there. She’s used to old people saying things that make no sense, and says as much -
Uh-huh. He looks at her two fingers touching his wrist like a hand of benediction.
Did I have any choice? She gives him the kind of ‘shhh’ you give your kid to comfort their crying.  But it’s not that.
I’m trying to take your pulse, Mr. Sheeran, please don’t talk. Silence as she counts his heartbeats... then takes her hand away and writes it down.
Okay.  You’re free. He looks at her.
Until later today (when I put you through all this again).
I’m here. The nurse smiles and we follow her as she heads out into the corridor.
...through the ministry of the Church may God give you pardon and peace, I absolve you from your sins in the name of the Father, and of the Son, and the Holy Spirit.
Amen.
Give thanks to the Lord, for He is good.... Frank doesn’t remember the prayer. The priest prompts him.
His mercy -
His mercy endures forever.
May He bring you safely to His kingdom in Heaven.  Amen.
Amen. The priest readies to leave.
I can come see you again if you want, after the Christmas holidays.
It’s Christmas?
Almost.
Okay.  I ain’t going nowhere. The priest heads out.
Father, could you do me a favor? Don’t close the door all the way. I don’t like that. Leave it open a little.

Sure. From outside the room, the door starts to close, but then stops just short of covering up our view of Frank in the room. As the priest’s footsteps echo in the hospital corridor, we can just make Frank out in the sliver of light between the edge of the door and frame - alone in his wheelchair with the little stack of photographs in his lap, slowly leafing through them.
